answer_html: \(\frac{dy}{dt}=-3\) and so Bob is walking towards the lamppost at 3ft/s.Notice the sign we get makes sense because we are told that each person is walking towards the lamp in the question!
answer_latex:
$\frac{dy}{dt}=-3$ and so Bob is walking \textbf{towards} the lamppost at 3ft/s.Notice the
sign we get makes sense because we are told that each person is walking
towards the lamp in the question!
hints_html:
This question heavily relies on understanding the problem and the diagram in part (a) and thus all notation here out refers to the diagram in part (a). The diagram labels the important triangles and values. The key relationships needed are in \(T_{1}\) (from Alice’s head to the lamp post to L), triangle APL, \(T_{2}\) (from Bob’s head to the lamp post to L), and triangle BPL. Let C denote the length of the segment AP and let D denote the length of the segment BP.

The next hints will be successions of understanding what the values are with respect to these letters.

We are given that

\(\frac{dx}{dt} = -4\) (notice that the negative is here since the size of x is decreasing over time as Alice and Bob are walking towards the lamppost).

Notice that the distance between the tips of the shadows is given by \(C + D\). Thus, we are also given that

\(\frac{d(C + D)}{dt} = \frac{dC}{dt} + \frac{dD}{dt} = -11\) (notice that the negative is here since the distance is decreasing over time as given by the question).

Bob’s distance to the lamp is y and so the speed he is walking is

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dt}.\end{aligned}\]

What do we expect the sign of this number to be in the end?

Use similar triangles for the triangles mentioned in hint 1 using the picture from part (a) and relate all these hints to create a solution.

hints_raw:
This question heavily relies on understanding the problem and the diagram in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2012/Question_5_(a)|part (a)]] and thus all notation here out refers to the diagram in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2012/Question_5_(a)|part (a)]]. The diagram labels the important triangles and values. The key relationships needed are in <math> T_{1} </math> (from Alice's head to the lamp post to L), triangle APL, <math> T_{2} </math> (from Bob's head to the lamp post to L), and triangle BPL. Let C denote the length of the segment AP and let D denote the length of the segment BP.

The next hints will be successions of understanding what the values are with respect to these letters.
We are given that 

<math> \frac{dx}{dt} = -4 </math> (notice that the negative is here since the size of ''x'' is decreasing over time as Alice and Bob are walking towards the lamppost).

Notice that the distance between the tips of the shadows is given by <math> C + D </math>. Thus, we are also given that

<math> \frac{d(C + D)}{dt}  = \frac{dC}{dt} + \frac{dD}{dt} = -11 </math> (notice that the negative is here since the distance is decreasing over time as given by the question).
Bob's distance to the lamp is y and so the speed he is walking is

:<math> \frac{dy}{dt} </math>.

What do we expect the sign of this number to be in the end?

Use similar triangles for the triangles mentioned in hint 1 using the picture from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2012/Question_5_(a)|part (a)]] and relate all these hints to create a solution.
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
The diagram from part a has been recopied for ease of reading

Proceeding via the hints, we are interested in solving for \(\frac{dy}{dt}\). We first note that triangles \(T_{2}\) and triangle BPL are similar (they share an angle and both contain a 90 degree angle). Thus, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{y}{9} = \frac{D}{15}.\end{aligned}\]

Multiplying by 15, reducing and differentiating with respect to time gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{5}{3}\frac{dy}{dt} = \frac{dD}{dt}.\end{aligned}\]

To solve for \(\frac{dy}{dt}\) we will need \(\frac{dD}{dt}\), the speed at which Bob’s shadow tip is changing. To do this we consider that the distance between the two tips is decreasing by 11ft/s and so

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dC}{dt} + \frac{dD}{dt} = -11.\end{aligned}\]

To determine \(\frac{dC}{dt}\) we turn to the similar triangle problem for Alice. Triangles \(T_{1}\) and triangle APL are similar (they share an angle and both contain a 90 degree angle). Thus, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{x}{10} = \frac{C}{15}\end{aligned}\]

Multiplying by 15, reducing and differentiating with respect to time gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{3}{2}\frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{dC}{dt}\end{aligned}\]

We are given that \(\frac{dx}{dt} = -4\) and so we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dC}{dt} = -6.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dD}{dt}=-11-\frac{dC}{dt}=-5\end{aligned}\]

and finally then that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dt}=\frac{3}{5}\frac{dD}{dt}=-\frac{3}{5}(5)=-3\end{aligned}\]

and so Bob is walking towards the lamppost at 3ft/s. Notice the sign we get makes sense because we are told that each person is walking towards the lamp in the question!

The diagram from part a has been recopied for ease of reading

Proceeding via the hints, we are interested in solving for \(\frac{dy}{dt}\). We first note that triangles BBob and triangle BPL are similar (they share an angle and both contain a 90 degree angle). Thus, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{D-y}{6} = \frac{D}{15}.\end{aligned}\]

Multiplying by 30, reducing and differentiating with respect to time gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dD}{dt} = \frac{5}{3}\frac{dy}{dt}.\end{aligned}\]

To solve for \(\frac{dy}{dt}\) we will need \(\frac{dD}{dt}\), the speed at which Bob’s shadow tip is changing. To do this we consider that the distance between the two tips is decreasing by 11ft/s and so

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dC}{dt} + \frac{dD}{dt} = -11.\end{aligned}\]

To determine \(\frac{dC}{dt}\) we turn to the similar triangle problem for Alice. Triangles AAlice and triangle APL are similar (they share an angle and both contain a 90 degree angle). Thus, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{C-x}{5} = \frac{C}{15}\end{aligned}\]

Multiplying by 15, reducing and differentiating with respect to time gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{3}{2}\frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{dC}{dt}\end{aligned}\]

We are given that \(\frac{dx}{dt} = -4\) and so we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dC}{dt} = -6.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dD}{dt}=-11-\frac{dC}{dt}=-5\end{aligned}\]

and finally then that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dt}=\frac{3}{5}\frac{dD}{dt}=-\frac{3}{5}(5)=-3\end{aligned}\]

and so Bob is walking towards the lamppost at 3ft/s. Notice the sign we get makes sense because we are told that each person is walking towards the lamp in the question!
sols_raw:
The diagram from part a has been recopied for ease of reading

[[File:MATH104Q5a2012.jpg|750px]]

Proceeding via the hints, we are interested in solving for <math>\frac{dy}{dt}</math>.  We first note that triangles <math>T_{2} </math> and triangle BPL are similar (they share an angle and both contain a 90 degree angle). Thus, we have that 

:<math> \frac{y}{9} = \frac{D}{15} </math>.

Multiplying by 15, reducing and differentiating with respect to time gives

:<math> \frac{5}{3}\frac{dy}{dt} = \frac{dD}{dt}</math>.

To solve for <math>\frac{dy}{dt}</math> we will need <math>\frac{dD}{dt}</math>, the speed at which Bob's shadow tip is changing.  To do this we consider that the distance between the two tips is decreasing by 11ft/s and so

:<math> \frac{dC}{dt} + \frac{dD}{dt} = -11 </math>.

To determine <math>\frac{dC}{dt}</math> we turn to the similar triangle problem for Alice.  Triangles <math>T_{1} </math> and triangle APL are similar (they share an angle and both contain a 90 degree angle). Thus, we have that 

:<math> \frac{x}{10} = \frac{C}{15} </math>

Multiplying by 15, reducing and differentiating with respect to time gives

:<math> \frac{3}{2}\frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{dC}{dt} </math>

We are given that <math>\frac{dx}{dt} = -4 </math> and so we have that

:<math> \frac{dC}{dt} = -6 </math>.

Therefore we have that

:<math>
\frac{dD}{dt}=-11-\frac{dC}{dt}=-5
</math>

and finally then that

:<math>
\frac{dy}{dt}=\frac{3}{5}\frac{dD}{dt}=-\frac{3}{5}(5)=-3
</math>

and so Bob is walking '''towards''' the lamppost at 3ft/s.  Notice the sign we get makes sense because we are told that each person is walking towards the lamp in the question!

Proceeding via the hints, we are interested in solving for <math>\frac{dy}{dt}</math>.  We first note that triangles ''BBob'' and triangle BPL are similar (they share an angle and both contain a 90 degree angle). Thus, we have that 

:<math> \frac{D-y}{6} = \frac{D}{15} </math>.

Multiplying by 30, reducing and differentiating with respect to time gives

:<math> \frac{dD}{dt} = \frac{5}{3}\frac{dy}{dt}</math>.

To solve for <math>\frac{dy}{dt}</math> we will need <math>\frac{dD}{dt}</math>, the speed at which Bob's shadow tip is changing.  To do this we consider that the distance between the two tips is decreasing by 11ft/s and so

:<math> \frac{dC}{dt} + \frac{dD}{dt} = -11 </math>.

To determine <math>\frac{dC}{dt}</math> we turn to the similar triangle problem for Alice.  Triangles ''AAlice'' and triangle APL are similar (they share an angle and both contain a 90 degree angle). Thus, we have that 

:<math> \frac{C-x}{5} = \frac{C}{15} </math>

Multiplying by 15, reducing and differentiating with respect to time gives

:<math> \frac{3}{2}\frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{dC}{dt} </math>

We are given that <math>\frac{dx}{dt} = -4 </math> and so we have that

:<math> \frac{dC}{dt} = -6 </math>.

Therefore we have that

:<math>
\frac{dD}{dt}=-11-\frac{dC}{dt}=-5
</math>

and finally then that

:<math>
\frac{dy}{dt}=\frac{3}{5}\frac{dD}{dt}=-\frac{3}{5}(5)=-3
</math>

and so Bob is walking '''towards''' the lamppost at 3ft/s.  Notice the sign we get makes sense because we are told that each person is walking towards the lamp in the question!
statement_html:
Alice is 5 ft tall and Bob is 6 ft tall. At some instant they are both walking towards a street lamp 15 ft high with Alice west of the lamp and Bob east of the lamp. Suppose at this instant, Alice is walking at 4 ft/s and the distance between the tips of their shadows is decreasing at 11 ft/s.

How fast is Bob walking?
statement_latex:
Alice is 5 ft tall and Bob is 6 ft tall. At some instant they are both
walking towards a street lamp 15 ft high with Alice west of the lamp and
Bob east of the lamp. Suppose at this instant, Alice is walking at 4
ft/s and the distance between the tips of their shadows is decreasing at
11 ft/s.

How fast is Bob walking?
statement_raw:
Alice is 5 ft tall and Bob is 6 ft tall.  At some instant they are both walking towards a street lamp 15 ft high with Alice west of the lamp and Bob east of the lamp.  Suppose at this instant, Alice is walking at 4 ft/s and the distance between the tips of their shadows is decreasing at 11 ft/s.

How fast is Bob walking?
